results.title: Naughty things (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Carol Haslam, Open University and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Psychology”.
Presents separate interviews with four young children, which are intended to illustrate Jean Piaget’s methods of clinical investigation and his conclusions about the moral development of children contained in his book entitled “Le Jugement moral chez l’enfant”. Introduction by Derek Wright.

results.title: Naughty nostalgia. - Volume 1 (E)
results.brief_description: This video contains three of the earliest known pornographic films of the 1920s era. Each is shown complete with the original title cards, honky tonk music track, vintage automobiles and black stockings and hats of the day.

results.title: Naughty cartoons (E)
results.brief_description: A patchy collection of cult, unusual and obscure ‘erotic’ based animation. As a whole overtly designed to titillate on the most obvious level (these animations being the least affective), with only a few having any merit. Generally an over-use of ‘visual friction’ throughout. Some of the better ones: Karl Krogsta’s clay animation Jack in the Fox, Susan Pittkraning’s drawing based Crocus, Lapoujade’s L’ombre De La Pomme (with jazz soundtrack). The fifteen plus cartoons represent pornographic animation from the early 1900’s to contemporary times.

results.title: Nature walkabout
results.creator_credit: Cardin Film Service, Vincent Serventy and William Copland
results.brief_description: Wildlife in and around the city of Perth and the southern areas and coastlines of West Australia. Shows a variety of animals going about their daily experiences with a main focus on birdlife. Written and photographed by Vincent and Carol Serventy. Narrated by Kevin Golsby.

results.title: Nature printing
results.creator_credit: TV Ed Productions and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: Kerrie Aulsebrook, an Education Officer at the Museum of Victoria, looks at the techniques of nature printing. Nature printing is transferring the image of something in nature, (such as fish, plants, feathers, shells, snakeskin), onto the surface of paper. Anything with a textured surface works well: fish have been used in this demonstration.

results.title: Nature or Nurture (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Diversity”.
Congenital dislocation of the hip in humans is caused by both genetic and environmental factors, and by the interaction between them. Illustrates the methodology involved in sorting out the different factors

results.title: Nature of matter: an atomic view
results.creator_credit: C R M Production and Steven Katten
results.brief_description: Visits Dr Erwin Meuller Laboratory Pennsylvania State University to demonstrate the field-ion microscope. Discusses wave particle duality and spectroscopy. Photographed by Isidore Mankofsky with music composed by Fred Karlin.
